title: 108_hr2539
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Violence Against Children Act of 2003". Congress finds that children under 18 make up a significant portion of crime victims, with high rates of sex crimes and kidnapping. They are also more likely to be victims of violent crime compared to adults. Many crimes against children go unreported, leading to long-lasting negative effects such as delayed development and substance abuse. Lack of resources in local agencies hinders their ability to protect children and families in need. Failure to pay child support is considered a form of neglect. Children who do not receive financial support are more likely to live in poverty, leading to inadequate education, lack of quality health care, and affordable housing. TITLE I--ENHANCED FEDERAL ROLE IN CRIMES AGAINST CHILDREN: Enhanced penalties for crimes against children. Title I of the United States Code is amended to include enhanced penalties for violence against children, with imprisonment for up to 10 years and fines for injuring a person under 18 years of age. Harsher penalties apply if the offense results in death, involves kidnapping, aggravated sexual abuse, or attempted murder. The circumstances include the offense occurring during travel by the defendant or victim. The text discusses penalties for offenses involving violence against children, with enhanced penalties if the offense occurs during travel across state lines or using interstate commerce. The use of firearms or other weapons that have traveled in interstate commerce also increases penalties. The text discusses enhanced penalties for crimes against children, including a review of state laws and sentencing practices. Additionally, it mentions enhanced assistance for criminal investigations and prosecutions by state and local law enforcement officials. The Attorney General provides assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions of violent crimes against minors at the request of states, tribes, or local governments. Priority is given to crimes involving offenders in multiple states or rural areas with limited resources. Federal assistance is available to state and local law enforcement agencies. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. Grants aim to train personnel, develop specialized units, implement effective policies, and enhance data collection for crimes against children. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children, providing personnel, training, and equipment for apprehension and adjudication of offenders. Grants aim to enhance data collection and communication systems, encourage cross-collaboration between law enforcement and child services agencies, and address the needs of Indian tribes in dealing with crimes against children. States, Indian tribal governments, or local governments seeking grants must submit an application to the Attorney General. The Attorney General awards grants to assist in law enforcement and prosecution of crimes against children. Applicants must describe the grant's purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. They must also consult with victim services programs and ensure federal funds supplement non-federal funds. Authorization of Appropriations: $25,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2008 to carry out activities funded under this section, ensuring compliance with specified regulations. SEC. 202. EDUCATION, PREVENTION, AND VICTIMS' ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for seminars, hotlines, training programs, informational materials, intervention services, awareness efforts, emergency medical treatment, and counseling for victims and their families. The Attorney General awards grants for education, prevention, intervention, and victims' assistance services for crimes against children. Grants are used for counseling victims and families, and increasing mental health professionals specializing in this area. States, tribal governments, local governments, or organizations must submit applications describing the grant's purposes, intended use of funds, and expected results. The grant funds require consultation with victim services programs experienced in crimes against children and certification of proper fund usage. Authorization of Appropriations.--$25,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2004 to 2008 to supplement non-Federal funds for activities under this section, with a waiver option for nongovernmental organizations in exceptional circumstances. Compliance with section 303 is required for the State, Indian tribal government, or nongovernmental organization operating the funded activities. TITLE III--NATIONWIDE PROGRAMS

SEC. 301. NATIONWIDE AMBER ALERT: States must establish a statewide AMBER Alert network for child abduction cases within 3 years of this Act.

SEC. 302. IMPROVED STATISTICAL GATHERING: States must use or develop protocols to use the National Incident-Based Reporting System for statistical data.

SEC. 303. NATIONAL SAFE HAVEN: Requirement for compliance with safe haven protocols for funded activities. Each State receiving grants under section 202 must have a statute allowing parents to leave a newborn with a hospital employee anonymously without penalty, collect family medical history with parent approval, search missing person databases after relinquishment, and publicize the State's Safe Haven law. Exceptions may apply if the newborn shows signs of abuse. If a newborn baby shows signs of abuse or intentional harm, exceptions may apply under the State's Safe Haven law. Improved Child Protection Services Programs under SEC. 304. States must submit a report on their child welfare program within 180 days of receiving funding, detailing record-keeping and child well-being verification processes. The GAO will report to Congress on State practices, including record maintenance and the effectiveness of the review system by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The States must report on their child welfare program within 180 days of funding, focusing on record-keeping and child well-being verification. The GAO will inform Congress about State practices and recommend legislative changes for the child welfare system. TITLE IV--CHILD SUPPORT ENFORCEMENT

SENSE OF THE SENATE ON TAX TREATMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT: Congress should pass legislation to extend Federal tax treatment on bad debt to nonpayment of child support by allowing deductions for unpaid child support and requiring unpaid amounts to be added to income for tax purposes.
